text: Through God we shall do valiantly: for he it is that shall tread down our enemies.
text_kjv: Through God we shall do valiantly: for he it is that shall tread down our enemies.
text_niv: With God we will gain the victory,and he will trample down our enemies.
text_esv: With God we shall do valiantly; it is he who will tread down our foes.
text_nlt: With God’s help we will do mighty things,for he will trample down our foes.
text_msg: In God we'll do our very best;he'll flatten the opposition for good.
text_nasb: Through God we shall do valiantly, And it is He who will tread down our adversaries.
context: Psalm 60 is attributed to David and carries the superscription indicating it was written after his conflicts with Aram Naharaim, Aram Zobah, and when Joab returned and killed twelve thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt. These were significant military campaigns marking David's expansion of Israel's territory and power. The geographical locations mentioned highlight the strategic importance of controlling trade routes and resource-rich areas. Aram Naharaim (Mesopotamia) and Aram Zobah represented powerful kingdoms to the north. Edom, located south of Judah, presented a constant threat. The Valley of Salt, likely near the Dead Sea, was a key battleground. The psalm reflects a period of initial setbacks or perceived abandonment by God before eventual victory. The opening verses express a sense of national humiliation and divine displeasure, possibly alluding to initial losses or difficulties encountered in these campaigns. The reference to ‘shaking’ the land and ‘tearing’ it open suggests instability or vulnerability. The psalm then transitions to a confident affirmation of God's power and promise of future triumph. It’s important to note that warfare in the ancient Near East was often viewed through a religious lens. Victory was attributed to the favor of the gods, and defeat to their displeasure. This psalm encapsulates that belief, acknowledging God's role in both hardship and triumph. Understanding the military context and the perceived role of divine intervention is crucial to interpreting the triumphant declaration in verse 12.
meaning: Psalm 60:12, "Through God we shall do valiantly: for he it is that shall tread down our enemies," serves as the culmination of a plea for divine intervention and restoration. It is a confident declaration of faith born out of a period of national hardship and perceived divine abandonment. The phrase “through God we shall do valiantly” emphasizes that Israel's strength and success do not originate from their own military might or strategic prowess. Instead, it is God's power working through them that enables them to achieve victory. The Hebrew word translated as “valiantly” (chayil) conveys not only courage but also strength, ability, and even wealth, suggesting that through God, they will not only overcome their enemies but also prosper and flourish. The second part of the verse, “for he it is that shall tread down our enemies,” reinforces the sovereignty and power of God over all nations. The imagery of “treading down” evokes the idea of complete subjugation and crushing defeat. It suggests that God will not merely assist them in battle, but will actively destroy their adversaries. This highlights the role of God as a warrior king, actively intervening in human affairs to protect his people and establish his kingdom. The verse, therefore, is not simply a statement of hope, but a profound theological declaration about the nature of God and his relationship with his chosen people. It affirms that God is both the source of their strength and the guarantor of their victory. It stands in contrast to the earlier lament, suggesting a renewed understanding of God’s faithfulness despite temporary setbacks. It ultimately conveys that true victory is not achieved through human effort alone, but through unwavering faith in God and reliance on his power.
application: Psalm 60:12 offers profound practical application for modern believers facing personal, professional, or societal challenges. Firstly, it reminds us to acknowledge God as the ultimate source of our strength and ability. In a world that often celebrates self-reliance and individual achievement, this verse calls us to humble ourselves and recognize that true success comes from dependence on God. We must actively seek His guidance, wisdom, and strength in all our endeavors, understanding that He is the one who empowers us to overcome obstacles. This means committing our plans to prayer, seeking His will in Scripture, and being open to His direction even when it differs from our own desires. Secondly, this verse challenges us to act with courage and boldness in the face of adversity. Knowing that God is on our side empowers us to step out in faith, even when we feel inadequate or afraid. It encourages us to take risks for His kingdom, to stand up for what is right, and to pursue our goals with passion and determination. This does not mean acting recklessly, but rather trusting that God will equip us for the challenges He calls us to face. Thirdly, Psalm 60:12 calls us to trust in God's ultimate victory over evil. While we may face setbacks and defeats in the short term, we can be confident that God will ultimately triumph over all injustice and oppression. This provides us with hope and perseverance in difficult times, knowing that our struggles are not in vain. We can actively participate in God's work by praying for justice, working for peace, and advocating for the marginalized. Finally, this verse encourages us to cultivate a perspective of gratitude, acknowledging that any victories we experience are ultimately due to God's grace and power. It reminds us to give Him the glory for our successes and to use our abilities and resources to serve Him and others. It encourages us to live lives of humility, recognizing that we are simply instruments in His hands.
prayer: Heavenly Father, in times of doubt and uncertainty, remind me of Your unwavering presence and power. Help me to trust in Your promises, even when I face seemingly insurmountable challenges. Grant me the courage to step out in faith, knowing that You are with me every step of the way. Empower me to live a life of purpose and impact, using my gifts and talents to advance Your kingdom. Thank you for being my strength, my refuge, and my hope. I declare that through you, I will do valiantly. Teach me to rely on You above myself, above human strength, above any resource of my own. Fill me with your Spirit to tread down any enemy that rises against me. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: To 'do valiantly' signifies acting with courage, strength, and skill, empowered by God. It's not mere human bravery but a God-given capacity to overcome obstacles and achieve victory, both spiritually and practically. It implies a proactive, fearless approach to challenges.
faqs.question: Q1 What does it mean to "do valiantly"?

faqs.answer: This verse can be applied to spiritual warfare by recognizing our battles are not merely physical but against spiritual forces. Through God's power, believers can resist temptation, overcome negative influences, and stand firm in their faith against spiritual attacks.
faqs.question: Q2 How does this verse relate to spiritual warfare today?

faqs.answer: God 'treading down our enemies' signifies His ultimate victory over all opposition, both visible and invisible. It's a declaration of His sovereign power and His commitment to protect His people and ensure that good ultimately triumphs over evil.
faqs.question: Q3 What does it mean for God to "tread down our enemies"?

faqs.answer: In the workplace, this verse encourages seeking God's guidance, acting ethically and with integrity, demonstrating resilience in the face of challenges, and trusting that God will provide the strength and wisdom needed to succeed while honoring Him.
faqs.question: Q4 How can I apply this verse in my workplace?

faqs.answer: This verse provides a resolution and hopeful affirmation after the psalm begins with lament and a sense of God's displeasure. It emphasizes that even after hardship, God's power can restore and lead to victory, showing His enduring faithfulness.
